input_schema.description: Desired street address/location

input_schema.name: Operation Type
input_schema.description: Operation Type: sale, rent or auction

input_schema.name: Object Type
input_schema.description: Object Type: apartment, house, land, commercial or other

input_schema.name: Max number of pages
input_schema.description: Max number of search pages to process (default is 1)

input_schema.name: From
input_schema.description: Minimum Price

input_schema.name: To
input_schema.description: Maximum Price

input_schema.name: From
input_schema.description: Minimum Area

input_schema.name: To
input_schema.description: Maximum Area

input_schema.name: Dataset ID
input_schema.description: Id of dataset where the data are located. If you need to use other input types like Key value store or raw JSON, look at Other data sources

input_schema.name: Check only clean dataset items
input_schema.description: Only clean dataset items will be loaded and use for duplications checking if datasetId option is provided.

input_schema.name: Fields
input_schema.description: List of fields in each item that will be checked for duplicates. Each given field must not be nested and it should contain only simple value (string or number). You can prepare your data with preCheckFunction.

input_schema.name: Pre-check function
input_schema.description: You can specify which fields should display in the debug OUTPUT to identify bad items. By default it shows all fields which may make it unnecessary big.

input_schema.name: Minimum duplications
input_schema.description: Minimum occurences to be included in the report. Defaults to 2

input_schema.name: Show indexes
input_schema.description: Indexes of the duplicate items will be shown in the OUTPUT report. Set to false if you don't need them.

input_schema.name: Show items
input_schema.description: Duplicate items will be pushed to a dataset. Set to false if you don't need them.

input_schema.name: Show missing fields
input_schema.description: Items where the values for the field is missing or is null or '' will be included in the report.

input_schema.name: Limit
input_schema.description: How many items will be checked. Default is all

input_schema.name: Offset
input_schema.description: From which item the checking will start. Use with limit to check specific items.

input_schema.name: Batch Size
input_schema.description: You can change number of loaded and processed items in each batch. This is only needed if you have really huge items.

input_schema.name: Key value store Record
input_schema.description: ID and record key if you want to load from KV store. Format is {keyValueStoreId}+{recordKey}, e.g. s5NJ77qFv8b4osiGR+MY-KEY

input_schema.name: Raw Data
input_schema.description: Raw JSON array you want to check.

input_schema.name: Usernames
input_schema.description: TikTok usernames (pure username, don't include the URL or @ symbol).

input_schema.name: Crawler type
input_schema.description:
Select the crawling engine:

Raw HTTP client (default) - High-performance crawling mode that uses raw HTTP requests to fetch the pages. It is faster and cheaper, but it might not work on all websites.
Headless web browser - Useful for modern websites with anti-scraping protections and JavaScript rendering. It recognizes common blocking patterns like CAPTCHAs and automatically retries blocked requests through new sessions. However, running web browsers is more expensive as it requires more computing resources and is slower. It is recommended to use at least 8 GB of RAM.

input_schema.name: 🍪 Cookies
input_schema.description: Cookie used to authorize actor with twitter.com. Install EditThisCookie chrome extension. Login to your twitter.com account. Click on the extension and export the twitter.com cookies. Insert the contents here

input_schema.name: Profile URL
input_schema.description: Twitter profile url

input_schema.name: Next page cursor
input_schema.description: Cursor value to resume scraping from

input_schema.name: Number of followers to scrape
input_schema.description: Number of followers to scrape

input_schema.name: ⏱️ Minimum wait duration
input_schema.description: Minimum duration in seconds to wait before scraping next page

input_schema.name: ⏱️ Maximum wait duration
input_schema.description: Maximum duration in seconds to wait before scraping next page

input_schema.name: Amazon products URL
input_schema.description: Fill in URLs of the Amazon products you want to scrape. e.g https://www.amazon.com/iPhone-Pro-128GB-Sierra-Blue/dp/B0BGYG5GSJ/

input_schema.name: Sort By
input_schema.description: Select the the criterion to be used in sorting the Reviews from amazon

input_schema.name: Maximum Number Of Reviews
input_schema.description: Fill in the maximum number of reviews to be extracted in multiples of 10. Each review page contains a maximum of 10 reviews. To extract all reviews leave blank

input_schema.name: Proxy Settings
input_schema.description: Set custom proxies or use proxies provided to Apify

Supported protocol:

HTTP(S), SOCKS5
{http|socks5}://{user:pass}@{hostname|ip-address}:port

Example: socks5://example.com:9000

Use mask to customize dataset name:

{ACTOR} = actor name
{DATE} = date (YYYYMMDD)
{TIME} = time (HHMMSS)

default: data-{ACTOR}-{DATE}-{TIME}

input_schema.name: Unique Column
input_schema.description: Column name from results to use as Key for Key-Value Storage. For example: product_id (must be unique).

input_schema.description: The product's ASIN (Amazon Standard Identification Number) if the URL field not provided, this field is required

input_schema.description: The product's page URL, if the asin field not provided, this field is required

input_schema.description: URLs to start with. It should be list or detail URL

input_schema.name: Maximum number of items
input_schema.description: Maximum number of items that you want to scrape

input_schema.name: End page on listings
input_schema.description: The page number that you want to end with. By default there is no end page.

input_schema.name: Extend output function
input_schema.description: Function that takes a JQuery handle ($) as argument and returns data that will be merged with the default output

input_schema.name: Custom map function
input_schema.description: Function that takes each of the objects as argument and returns data that will be mapped by the function itself.

input_schema.name: Max products
input_schema.description: Specify maximum number of products you want to extract data for. Skip this field if you need all products from the provided categories.

input_schema.name: Max reviews
input_schema.description: Specify maximum number of reviews you want to extract for individual products. Skip this field if you need all reviews.

input_schema.name: Simple results
input_schema.description: Check this field if you only need basic product information displayed on category page. Product detail pages won't be crawled with simpleResults option checked. No reviews will be extracted as well.

input_schema.name: Proxy Configuration
input_schema.description: Use either Apify proxies or your own. Allegro Scraper works best with 'RESIDENTIAL' proxy group. If you choose Poland as a proxy country, requests may be blocked less intensively. However, the capacity of Polish residential proxies is limited, which slows the actor down. You can also experiment with datacenter proxies, mainly from 'SHADER' group. Just note that Allegro tends to block datacenter proxies a lot.

input_schema.name: Monitoring suite name
input_schema.description: Name of your monitoring suite. It will be used in notifications and to identify related resources in the Apify dashboard.

input_schema.name: Type of target
input_schema.description: Only one type of target can be monitored by a single monitoring suite. If you want to watch more types, create more monitoring suites.

input_schema.name: Target name patterns
input_schema.description: Regular expressions that will be matched against selected actors / tasks or datasets under your Apify account. All matching targets will then be monitored by this monitoring suite. This is typically also the fastest way to select a single target. Just type its full name. Datasets are going to be automatically group by these patterns when dashboard statistics is counted for dataset target type.

input_schema.name: Target IDs
input_schema.description: If for whatever reason the Target name pattern option does not suit you, targets can also be specified by providing their IDs, as found in your Apify dashboard.

input_schema.name: Max items to be checked
input_schema.description: Last items to be checked. If 100 is passed, only last hundred runs/datasets will be checked.

input_schema.name: URLs to check

A static list of URLs to check for captchas. To be able to add new URLs on the fly, enable the Use request queue option.

input_schema.name: Enabled
input_schema.description: Will save HTML for Cheerio and HTML + screenshot for Puppeteer/Playwright

input_schema.name: Link Selector
input_schema.description:
A CSS selector saying which links on the page (<a> elements with href attribute) shall be followed and added to the request queue. This setting only applies if Use request queue is enabled. To filter the links added to the queue, use the Pseudo-URLs setting.

If Link selector is empty, the page links are ignored.

For details, see Link selector in README.

input_schema.name: Pseudo-URLs
input_schema.description:
Specifies what kind of URLs found by Link selector should be added to the request queue. A pseudo-URL is a URL with regular expressions enclosed in [] brackets, e.g. http://www.example.com/[.*]. This setting only applies if the Use request queue option is enabled.

If Pseudo-URLs are omitted, the actor enqueues all links matched by the Link selector.

For details, see Pseudo-URLs in README.

input_schema.name: Repeat checks on provided URLs
input_schema.description: Will access each URL multiple times. Useful to test the same URL or bypass blocking of the first page.

input_schema.name: Max number of pages checked per domain
input_schema.description:
The maximum number of pages that the checker will load. The checker will stop when this limit is reached. It's always a good idea to set this limit in order to prevent excess platform usage for misconfigured scrapers. Note that the actual number of pages loaded might be slightly higher than this value.

If set to 0, there is no limit.

input_schema.name: Maximum concurrent pages checked per domain
input_schema.description: Specifies the maximum number of pages that can be processed by the checker in parallel for one domain. The checker automatically increases and decreases concurrency based on available system resources. This option enables you to set an upper limit, for example to reduce the load on a target website.

input_schema.name: Maximum number of concurrent domains checked
input_schema.description: Specifies the maximum number of domains that should be checked at a time. This setting is relevant when passing in more than one URL to check.

input_schema.name: Retire browser instance after request count
input_schema.description: How often will the browser itself rotate. Pick a higher number for smaller consumption, pick a lower number to rotate (test) more proxies.

input_schema.name: Usernames
input_schema.description: Usernames to search for (e.g. zuck)

input_schema.description: Your proxy configuration from Apify

input_schema.description: Maximum number of items you want to scrape per run. It will automatically paginate through to each URL, until it reaches the limit.

input_schema.name: Max items per URL
input_schema.description: Instead of specifying Max items, you can specify how many items you want to scrape per URL. It will automatically paginate through to each listing URL of products that you provide in Start URLs. Leave this field blank if you want to use Max items instead.

input_schema.name: Shipping to
input_schema.description: Select country to get shipping price for. Select 'Do not scrape shipping price' if you don't need it. It will make the actor run faster.

input_schema.name: Results Offset
input_schema.description: Results offset. 0 (default) is the first page, 60 is the 2nd page, 120 is the 3rd page...

input_schema.name: Results Per Page
input_schema.description: Number of results per page. Default is 60

input_schema.name: Filter or sort results by categories
input_schema.description: Input filterValue to filter Google Shopping results by price, band... The filterValue can be found in shopping results response. To sort the results, default is Relevance, other options: Review score: 'p_ord:rv', Price - low to high: 'p_ord:p', Price - hight to low: 'p_ord:pd'.

input_schema.name: Device
input_schema.description: Device can be "desktop", "mobile" or "tablet.

input_schema.name: Save HTML
input_schema.description: Include HTML in JSON response

input_schema.name: Output CSV friendly format
input_schema.description: Include shopping results data, use for CSV format

input_schema.name: Search
input_schema.description: Search title or content for specific Keywords

input_schema.name: Limit
input_schema.description: Limit number of results

input_schema.name: Format
input_schema.description: Content Format

input_schema.name: Run mode
input_schema.description:
This property indicates the scraper's mode of operation. In DEVELOPMENT mode, the scraper ignores page timeouts, doesn't use sessionPool, opens pages one by one and enables debugging via Chrome DevTools. Open the live view tab or the container URL to access the debugger. Further debugging options can be configured in the Advanced configuration section. PRODUCTION mode disables debugging and enables timeouts and concurrency.

For details, see Run mode in README.

input_schema.name: Start URLs
input_schema.description:
A static list of URLs to scrape.

For details, see Start URLs in README.

input_schema.name: URL #fragments identify unique pages
input_schema.description: Indicates that URL fragments (e.g. http://example.com#fragment) should be included when checking whether a URL has already been visited or not. Typically, URL fragments are used for page navigation only and therefore they should be ignored, as they don't identify separate pages. However, some single-page websites use URL fragments to display different pages; in such a case, this option should be enabled.

input_schema.name: Link selector
input_schema.description:
A CSS selector saying which links on the page (<a> elements with href attribute) shall be followed and added to the request queue. To filter the links added to the queue, use the Pseudo-URLs and/or Glob patterns setting.

If Link selector is empty, the page links are ignored.

For details, see Link selector in README.

input_schema.name: Glob Patterns
input_schema.description: Glob patterns to match links in the page that you want to enqueue. Combine with Link selector to tell the scraper where to find links. Omitting the Glob patterns will cause the scraper to enqueue all links matched by the Link selector.

input_schema.name: Pseudo-URLs
input_schema.description:
Specifies what kind of URLs found by Link selector should be added to the request queue. A pseudo-URL is a URL with regular expressions enclosed in [] brackets, e.g. http://www.example.com/[.*].

If Pseudo-URLs are omitted, the actor enqueues all links matched by the Link selector.

For details, see Pseudo-URLs in README.

input_schema.name: Exclude Glob Patterns
input_schema.description: Glob patterns to match links in the page that you want to exclude from being enqueued.

input_schema.name: Page function
input_schema.description:
JavaScript (ES6) function that is executed in the context of every page loaded in the Chrome browser. Use it to scrape data from the page, perform actions or add new URLs to the request queue.

For details, see Page function in README.

input_schema.name: Inject jQuery
input_schema.description: If enabled, the scraper will inject the jQuery library into every web page loaded, before Page function is invoked. Note that the jQuery object ($) will not be registered into global namespace in order to avoid conflicts with libraries used by the web page. It can only be accessed through context.jQuery in Page function.

input_schema.name: Proxy configuration
input_schema.description:
Specifies proxy servers that will be used by the scraper in order to hide its origin.

For details, see Proxy configuration in README.

input_schema.name: Proxy rotation
input_schema.description: This property indicates the strategy of proxy rotation and can only be used in conjunction with Apify Proxy. The recommended setting automatically picks the best proxies from your available pool and rotates them evenly, discarding proxies that become blocked or unresponsive. If this strategy does not work for you for any reason, you may configure the scraper to either use a new proxy for each request, or to use one proxy as long as possible, until the proxy fails. IMPORTANT: This setting will only use your available Apify Proxy pool, so if you don't have enough proxies for a given task, no rotation setting will produce satisfactory results.

input_schema.name: Session pool name
input_schema.description: Use only english alphanumeric characters dashes and underscores. A session is a representation of a user. It has it's own IP and cookies which are then used together to emulate a real user. Usage of the sessions is controlled by the Proxy rotation option. By providing a session pool name, you enable sharing of those sessions across multiple actor runs. This is very useful when you need specific cookies for accessing the websites or when a lot of your proxies are already blocked. Instead of trying randomly, a list of working sessions will be saved and a new actor run can reuse those sessions. Note that the IP lock on sessions expires after 24 hours, unless the session is used again in that window.

input_schema.name: Initial cookies
input_schema.description: A JSON array with cookies that will be set to every Chrome browser tab opened before loading the page, in the format accepted by Puppeteer's Page.setCookie() function. This option is useful for transferring a logged-in session from an external web browser. For details how to do this, read this help article.

input_schema.name: Use Chrome
input_schema.description: If enabled, the scraper will use a real Chrome browser instead of Chromium bundled with Puppeteer. This option may help bypass certain anti-scraping protections, but might make the scraper unstable. Use at your own risk 🙂

input_schema.name: Run browsers in headless mode
input_schema.description: By default, browsers run in headless mode. You can toggle this off to run them in headful mode, which can help with certain rare anti-scraping protections but is slower and more costly.

input_schema.name: Ignore SSL errors
input_schema.description: If enabled, the scraper will ignore SSL/TLS certificate errors. Use at your own risk.

input_schema.name: Ignore CORS and CSP
input_schema.description: If enabled, the scraper will ignore Content Security Policy (CSP) and Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS) settings of visited pages and requested domains. This enables you to freely use XHR/Fetch to make HTTP requests from Page function.

input_schema.name: Download media files
input_schema.description: If enabled, the scraper will download media such as images, fonts, videos and sound files, as usual. Disabling this option might speed up the scrape, but certain websites could stop working correctly.

input_schema.name: Download CSS files
input_schema.description: If enabled, the scraper will download CSS files with stylesheets, as usual. Disabling this option may speed up the scrape, but certain websites could stop working correctly, and the live view will not look as cool.

input_schema.name: Max page retries
input_schema.description:
The maximum number of times the scraper will retry to load each web page on error, in case of a page load error or an exception thrown by Page function.

If set to 0, the page will be considered failed right after the first error.

input_schema.name: Max pages per run
input_schema.description:
The maximum number of pages that the scraper will load. The scraper will stop when this limit is reached. It's always a good idea to set this limit in order to prevent excess platform usage for misconfigured scrapers. Note that the actual number of pages loaded might be slightly higher than this value.

If set to 0, there is no limit.

input_schema.name: Max result records
input_schema.description:
The maximum number of records that will be saved to the resulting dataset. The scraper will stop when this limit is reached.

If set to 0, there is no limit.

input_schema.name: Max crawling depth
input_schema.description:
Specifies how many links away from Start URLs the scraper will descend. This value is a safeguard against infinite crawling depths for misconfigured scrapers. Note that pages added using context.enqueuePage() in Page function are not subject to the maximum depth constraint.

If set to 0, there is no limit.

input_schema.name: Max concurrency
input_schema.description: Specified the maximum number of pages that can be processed by the scraper in parallel. The scraper automatically increases and decreases concurrency based on available system resources. This option enables you to set an upper limit, for example to reduce the load on a target web server.

input_schema.name: Page load timeout
input_schema.description: The maximum amount of time the scraper will wait for a web page to load, in seconds. If the web page does not load in this timeframe, it is considered to have failed and will be retried (subject to Max page retries), similarly as with other page load errors.

input_schema.name: Page function timeout
input_schema.description: The maximum amount of time the scraper will wait for Page function to execute, in seconds. It's a good idea to set this limit, to ensure that unexpected behavior in page function will not get the scraper stuck.

input_schema.name: Navigation waits until
input_schema.description:
Contains a JSON array with names of page events to wait, before considering a web page fully loaded. The scraper will wait until all of the events are triggered in the web page before executing Page function. Available events are domcontentloaded, load, networkidle2 and networkidle0.

For details, see waitUntil option in Puppeteer's Page.goto() function documentation.

input_schema.name: Pre-navigation hooks
input_schema.description: Async functions that are sequentially evaluated before the navigation. Good for setting additional cookies or browser properties before navigation. The function accepts two parameters, crawlingContext and gotoOptions, which are passed to the page.goto() function the crawler calls to navigate.

input_schema.name: Post-navigation hooks
input_schema.description: Async functions that are sequentially evaluated after the navigation. Good for checking if the navigation was successful. The function accepts crawlingContext as the only parameter.

input_schema.name: Insert breakpoint
input_schema.description:
This property has no effect if Run mode is set to PRODUCTION. When set to DEVELOPMENT it inserts a breakpoint at the selected location in every page the scraper visits. Execution of code stops at the breakpoint until manually resumed in the DevTools window accessible via Live View tab or Container URL. Additional breakpoints can be added by adding debugger; statements within your Page function.

See Run mode in README for details.

input_schema.name: Debug log
input_schema.description: If enabled, the actor log will include debug messages. Beware that this can be quite verbose. Use context.log.debug('message') to log your own debug messages from Page function.

input_schema.name: Browser log
input_schema.description: If enabled, the actor log will include console messages produced by JavaScript executed by the web pages (e.g. using console.log()). Beware that this may result in the log being flooded by error messages, warnings and other messages of little value, especially with high concurrency.

input_schema.name: Custom data
input_schema.description: A custom JSON object that is passed to Page function as context.customData. This setting is useful when invoking the scraper via API, in order to pass some arbitrary parameters to your code.

input_schema.name: Dataset name
input_schema.description: Name or ID of the dataset that will be used for storing results. If left empty, the default dataset of the run will be used.

input_schema.name: Key-value store name
input_schema.description: Name or ID of the key-value store that will be used for storing records. If left empty, the default key-value store of the run will be used.

input_schema.name: Request queue name
input_schema.description: Name of the request queue that will be used for storing requests. If left empty, the default request queue of the run will be used.

input_schema.name: Profile URLs
input_schema.description: URLs of Product Hunt profiles you want to scrape data from

input_schema.name: Proxy Configuration
input_schema.description: Use either automatic Apify proxies or your own

input_schema.name: Start URLs
input_schema.description: URLs to start with. It should be list or detail URL

input_schema.description: Select mode of the actor

input_schema.name: Proxy
input_schema.description: You can use proxy from your account's country if needed for extra safety.

input_schema.name: ⏱️ Minimum wait duration

input_schema.name: ⏱️ Maximum wait duration
input_schema.description: Maximum duration in seconds to wait before scraping next page

input_schema.name: Proxy configuration

input_schema.name: Source dataset ID
input_schema.description: The dataset that contains Google reviews that should be analyzed.

input_schema.name: Industry
input_schema.description: The industry of the businesses reviewed. Choosing an NLP model for a specific industry would give better results for Google reviews targeting that industry. If not sure, pick the general purpose 'General' NLP model.

0 is no limit.

JavaScript function executed on every page (inside the browser). Customise it if necessary.

input_schema.name: Respect URL pattern
input_schema.description:
Specifies what kind of URLs should be scrapped. A pseudo-URL is a URL with regular expressions enclosed in [] brackets, e.g. https://www.doctolib.fr/[.*].

If Pseudo-URLs are omitted, the actor only crawls the Start-URLs.

For details, see Pseudo-URLs.

input_schema.name: ⛏️ Select action to perform
input_schema.description: First run the actor with 'Find tables' option to get possible output data table formats. Then choose the desired format and use it's table number to scrape the data by choosing 'Scrape' option

input_schema.name: 🍪 Cookies
input_schema.description: Cookie used to authorize actor with website. Install EditThisCookie chrome extension. Login to your website account. Click on the extension and export the website cookies. Insert the contents here

input_schema.name: URL to scrape

input_schema.name: Column name mappings
input_schema.description: Assign column names to data obtained from scraping. By default scraper will assign 0 based number to each column. You will need to manually assign names to these columns by mapping column names to column numbers in 'Find tables' output

input_schema.name: Table number to scrape
input_schema.description: Scraper will automatically detact all the tables in the given page. But to decide which table to scrape, scraper needs either sample data or table number. Run the scraper with 'Find tables' action and choose the value from 'Table number' column from the output dataset. Choose the value from the row of your preferred data format

input_schema.name: Include additional columns
input_schema.description: Include additional columns that are not included in columns mappings. These columns will have names like column_1, column_2, etc

input_schema.name: Next page selector
input_schema.description: Copy the CSS selector of the next page button or link. Leave it empty if the method of loading more data is by scrolling down. To get the selector of next page element, Right click on the element and click 'Inspect element'. Then on the popup, Right click on the highlighted element and click on 'Copy > Copy selector'

input_schema.name: Start URLs
input_schema.description: URLs to start with. It should be a post or a reel URL

input_schema.name: Proxy configuration
input_schema.description: Select proxies to be used by your crawler.

input_schema.name: Select action to perform
input_schema.description: Actor will decide what kind of data it needs to scrape and from where it should scrape it based on selected action

input_schema.name: Start from cursor
input_schema.description: Use this field if you want to resume scraping from where the scraper stopped last time. You can find this value in default storage of scraper runs under lastCursor key

input_schema.name: Total number of records required
input_schema.description: Leave this field empty if you want to scrape all profiles.

input_schema.name: Proxy
input_schema.description: You can use proxy from your account's country if needed for extra safety.

input_schema.name: Minimum wait duration
input_schema.description: Minimum duration in seconds to wait before scraping next page

input_schema.name: Maximum wait duration
input_schema.description: Maximum duration in seconds to wait before scraping next page

input_schema.name: Number of Pages (1 page = 30 jobs) , if you want to scrape more then 20 pages go in options and change the timeout to 30000 (30 pages its aproximatly 1 hour)
input_schema.description: The number of pages you want from the jobs.

input_schema.name: Job
input_schema.description: The job title you want to scrape from Glassdoor.

input_schema.name: Location
input_schema.description: The location of the job you want to scrape from Glassdoor.

input_schema.name: Select action to perform
input_schema.description: Actor will decide what kind of data it needs to scrape and from where it should scrape it based on selected action

input_schema.name: App ID
input_schema.description: The Google Play id of the application (the ?id= parameter on the url).

input_schema.name: #️⃣ Total number of records required
input_schema.description: Leave this field empty if you want to scrape all items.

input_schema.name: Start from cursor
input_schema.description: Use this field if you want to resume scraping from where the scraper stopped last time. You can find this value in default storage of scraper runs under lastCursor key

input_schema.name: Proxy
input_schema.description: You can use proxy from your account's country if needed for extra safety.

input_schema.name: ⏱️ Minimum wait duration
input_schema.description: Minimum duration in seconds to wait before scraping next page

input_schema.name: ⏱️ Maximum wait duration
input_schema.description: Maximum duration in seconds to wait before scraping next page

input_schema.name: Run mode
input_schema.description:
This property indicates the scraper's mode of operation. In DEVELOPMENT mode, the scraper ignores page timeouts, doesn't use sessionPool, opens pages one by one and enables debugging via Chrome DevTools. Open the live view tab or the container URL to access the debugger. Further debugging options can be configured in the Advanced configuration section. PRODUCTION mode disables debugging and enables timeouts and concurrency.

For details, see Run mode in README.

input_schema.name: Start URLs
input_schema.description:
A static list of URLs to scrape.

For details, see Start URLs in README.

input_schema.name: URL #fragments identify unique pages
input_schema.description: Indicates that URL fragments (e.g. http://example.com#fragment) should be included when checking whether a URL has already been visited or not. Typically, URL fragments are used for page navigation only and therefore they should be ignored, as they don't identify separate pages. However, some single-page websites use URL fragments to display different pages; in such a case, this option should be enabled.

input_schema.name: Link selector
input_schema.description:
A CSS selector saying which links on the page (<a> elements with href attribute) shall be followed and added to the request queue. To filter the links added to the queue, use the Pseudo-URLs and/or Glob patterns setting.

If Link selector is empty, the page links are ignored.

For details, see Link selector in README.

input_schema.name: Glob Patterns
input_schema.description: Glob patterns to match links in the page that you want to enqueue. Combine with Link selector to tell the scraper where to find links. Omitting the Glob patterns will cause the scraper to enqueue all links matched by the Link selector.

input_schema.name: Pseudo-URLs
input_schema.description:
Specifies what kind of URLs found by Link selector should be added to the request queue. A pseudo-URL is a URL with regular expressions enclosed in [] brackets, e.g. http://www.example.com/[.*].

If Pseudo-URLs are omitted, the actor enqueues all links matched by the Link selector.

For details, see Pseudo-URLs in README.

input_schema.name: Exclude Glob Patterns
input_schema.description: Glob patterns to match links in the page that you want to exclude from being enqueued.

input_schema.name: Page function
input_schema.description:
JavaScript (ES6) function that is executed in the context of every page loaded in the Chrome browser. Use it to scrape data from the page, perform actions or add new URLs to the request queue.

For details, see Page function in README.

input_schema.name: Inject jQuery
input_schema.description: If enabled, the scraper will inject the jQuery library into every web page loaded, before Page function is invoked. Note that the jQuery object ($) will not be registered into global namespace in order to avoid conflicts with libraries used by the web page. It can only be accessed through context.jQuery in Page function.

input_schema.name: Proxy configuration
input_schema.description:
Specifies proxy servers that will be used by the scraper in order to hide its origin.

For details, see Proxy configuration in README.

input_schema.name: Proxy rotation
input_schema.description: This property indicates the strategy of proxy rotation and can only be used in conjunction with Apify Proxy. The recommended setting automatically picks the best proxies from your available pool and rotates them evenly, discarding proxies that become blocked or unresponsive. If this strategy does not work for you for any reason, you may configure the scraper to either use a new proxy for each request, or to use one proxy as long as possible, until the proxy fails. IMPORTANT: This setting will only use your available Apify Proxy pool, so if you don't have enough proxies for a given task, no rotation setting will produce satisfactory results.

input_schema.name: Session pool name
input_schema.description: Use only english alphanumeric characters dashes and underscores. A session is a representation of a user. It has it's own IP and cookies which are then used together to emulate a real user. Usage of the sessions is controlled by the Proxy rotation option. By providing a session pool name, you enable sharing of those sessions across multiple actor runs. This is very useful when you need specific cookies for accessing the websites or when a lot of your proxies are already blocked. Instead of trying randomly, a list of working sessions will be saved and a new actor run can reuse those sessions. Note that the IP lock on sessions expires after 24 hours, unless the session is used again in that window.

input_schema.name: Initial cookies
input_schema.description: A JSON array with cookies that will be set to every Chrome browser tab opened before loading the page, in the format accepted by Puppeteer's Page.setCookie() function. This option is useful for transferring a logged-in session from an external web browser. For details how to do this, read this help article.

input_schema.name: Use Chrome
input_schema.description: If enabled, the scraper will use a real Chrome browser instead of Chromium bundled with Puppeteer. This option may help bypass certain anti-scraping protections, but might make the scraper unstable. Use at your own risk 🙂

input_schema.name: Run browsers in headless mode
input_schema.description: By default, browsers run in headless mode. You can toggle this off to run them in headful mode, which can help with certain rare anti-scraping protections but is slower and more costly.

input_schema.name: Ignore SSL errors
input_schema.description: If enabled, the scraper will ignore SSL/TLS certificate errors. Use at your own risk.

input_schema.name: Ignore CORS and CSP
input_schema.description: If enabled, the scraper will ignore Content Security Policy (CSP) and Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS) settings of visited pages and requested domains. This enables you to freely use XHR/Fetch to make HTTP requests from Page function.

input_schema.name: Download media files
input_schema.description: If enabled, the scraper will download media such as images, fonts, videos and sound files, as usual. Disabling this option might speed up the scrape, but certain websites could stop working correctly.

input_schema.name: Download CSS files
input_schema.description: If enabled, the scraper will download CSS files with stylesheets, as usual. Disabling this option may speed up the scrape, but certain websites could stop working correctly, and the live view will not look as cool.

input_schema.name: Max page retries
input_schema.description:
The maximum number of times the scraper will retry to load each web page on error, in case of a page load error or an exception thrown by Page function.

If set to 0, the page will be considered failed right after the first error.

input_schema.name: Max pages per run
input_schema.description:
The maximum number of pages that the scraper will load. The scraper will stop when this limit is reached. It's always a good idea to set this limit in order to prevent excess platform usage for misconfigured scrapers. Note that the actual number of pages loaded might be slightly higher than this value.

If set to 0, there is no limit.

input_schema.name: Max result records
input_schema.description:
The maximum number of records that will be saved to the resulting dataset. The scraper will stop when this limit is reached.

If set to 0, there is no limit.

input_schema.name: Max crawling depth
input_schema.description:
Specifies how many links away from Start URLs the scraper will descend. This value is a safeguard against infinite crawling depths for misconfigured scrapers. Note that pages added using context.enqueuePage() in Page function are not subject to the maximum depth constraint.

If set to 0, there is no limit.

input_schema.name: Max concurrency
input_schema.description: Specified the maximum number of pages that can be processed by the scraper in parallel. The scraper automatically increases and decreases concurrency based on available system resources. This option enables you to set an upper limit, for example to reduce the load on a target web server.

input_schema.name: Page load timeout
input_schema.description: The maximum amount of time the scraper will wait for a web page to load, in seconds. If the web page does not load in this timeframe, it is considered to have failed and will be retried (subject to Max page retries), similarly as with other page load errors.

input_schema.name: Page function timeout
input_schema.description: The maximum amount of time the scraper will wait for Page function to execute, in seconds. It's a good idea to set this limit, to ensure that unexpected behavior in page function will not get the scraper stuck.

input_schema.name: Navigation waits until
input_schema.description:
Contains a JSON array with names of page events to wait, before considering a web page fully loaded. The scraper will wait until all of the events are triggered in the web page before executing Page function. Available events are domcontentloaded, load, networkidle2 and networkidle0.

For details, see waitUntil option in Puppeteer's Page.goto() function documentation.

input_schema.name: Pre-navigation hooks
input_schema.description: Async functions that are sequentially evaluated before the navigation. Good for setting additional cookies or browser properties before navigation. The function accepts two parameters, crawlingContext and gotoOptions, which are passed to the page.goto() function the crawler calls to navigate.

input_schema.name: Post-navigation hooks
input_schema.description: Async functions that are sequentially evaluated after the navigation. Good for checking if the navigation was successful. The function accepts crawlingContext as the only parameter.

input_schema.name: Insert breakpoint
input_schema.description:
This property has no effect if Run mode is set to PRODUCTION. When set to DEVELOPMENT it inserts a breakpoint at the selected location in every page the scraper visits. Execution of code stops at the breakpoint until manually resumed in the DevTools window accessible via Live View tab or Container URL. Additional breakpoints can be added by adding debugger; statements within your Page function.

See Run mode in README for details.

input_schema.name: Debug log
input_schema.description: If enabled, the actor log will include debug messages. Beware that this can be quite verbose. Use context.log.debug('message') to log your own debug messages from Page function.

input_schema.name: Browser log
input_schema.description: If enabled, the actor log will include console messages produced by JavaScript executed by the web pages (e.g. using console.log()). Beware that this may result in the log being flooded by error messages, warnings and other messages of little value, especially with high concurrency.

input_schema.name: Custom data
input_schema.description: A custom JSON object that is passed to Page function as context.customData. This setting is useful when invoking the scraper via API, in order to pass some arbitrary parameters to your code.

input_schema.name: Dataset name
input_schema.description: Name or ID of the dataset that will be used for storing results. If left empty, the default dataset of the run will be used.

input_schema.name: Key-value store name
input_schema.description: Name or ID of the key-value store that will be used for storing records. If left empty, the default key-value store of the run will be used.

input_schema.name: Request queue name
input_schema.description: Name of the request queue that will be used for storing requests. If left empty, the default request queue of the run will be used.

input_schema.name: Message
input_schema.description: Just enter your hello world message.

input_schema.name: Start URLS
input_schema.description: Urls to be evaluated directly

input_schema.description: Select a category to be evaluated

input_schema.description: URLs to start with.

input_schema.name: Maximum number of listing items
input_schema.description: Maximum number of items that you want as output. Default is all

input_schema.name: List end page
input_schema.description: The page number that you want to end with. By default there is no end page. This is applies to all search request and startUrls individually.

input_schema.description: Function that takes a JQuery handle ($) as argument and returns data that will be merged with the default output

input_schema.name: Custom map function
input_schema.description: Function that takes each of the objects as argument and returns data that will be mapped by the function itself.

input_schema.description: Select proxies to be used by your crawler.

input_schema.name: Search terms or URLs
input_schema.description:
Google Search terms (e.g. Cars) and/or full URLs (e.g. https://www.google.com/search?hl=en&num=100&q=Cars&tbm=vid).

Please enter one item per line.

input_schema.name: Max pages per search term or URL
input_schema.description: Maximum number of Google Search result pages crawled for each search term or URL. Please note that Google limits the number of search results pages it shows you to between 300 and 400.

input_schema.name: Results per Google page
input_schema.description:
Number of search results for each Google result page. By default, Google Search returns 10 results per page. The allowed values are: 10, 20, 30, 40, 50 and 100.
Since our Free plan contains 100 free SERP proxies, and every request consumes 1 proxy, you will get exactly 100 free requests, no matter the amount of results you will get per each.

This is why to get maximum value from this scraper, we recommend setting up this parameter to its maximum, 100.

input_schema.name: Mobile results
input_schema.description: If checked, the scraper will return results for the mobile version of the Google search. By default, desktop results are returned.

input_schema.name: CSV friendly output (1 result per 1 row)
input_schema.description:
This option allows to arrange the results in a structure suitable for CSV format. If checked, Related queries with respective URLs, People Also Ask, reviews and prices will not be included. Only organic and paid results will be included.

Note: please take into account that displayed paid results are still heavily dependent on your location and browsing history.

input_schema.name: Country
input_schema.description: Country determines the IP address of the proxy used for the search and the Google Search domain (e.g. google.es for Spain). By default, the actor uses United States (google.com).

input_schema.name: Exact location (Google UULE parameter)
input_schema.description: The code for the exact location for the Google search. It's passed to Google Search as the uule URL query parameter. You can use the UULE code generator. Learn more about emulating local search.

input_schema.name: Max concurrency
input_schema.description: Maximum number of search results pages the scraper will load in parallel. A higher number means you will get your results faster, but it will also burn through your available proxies quicker.

input_schema.name: Save HTML to dataset
input_schema.description: If checked, the HTML of the Google Search results pages will be stored to the default dataset, under the html property. This is useful if you need to process the HTML, but it makes the dataset large and reduces performance.

input_schema.name: Save HTML to key-value store
input_schema.description: If checked, the HTML of the Google Search results pages will be stored to the default key-value store and links to the files stored to the dataset under the htmlSnapshotUrl property. This is useful for debugging, since you can easily view the pages in the browser. However, the use of this feature may present some performance penalty.

input_schema.name: Include unfiltered results
input_schema.description: If checked, the lower quality results that Google normally filters out will be included. This usually consists of a few hundred extra results.

input_schema.description: startUrls

input_schema.name: Scrape detail page
input_schema.description: If enable, the scaper will scape detail page. This can get more information but cost more time and resource. Use it when you really need it.

input_schema.name: Save HTML
input_schema.description: Include HTML in JSON response

input_schema.name: Start URLs
input_schema.description: URLs to start with

input_schema.name: Use request queue
input_schema.description: Request queue enables recursive crawling and the use of Pseudo-URLs, Link selector and context.enqueueRequest().

input_schema.name: Pseudo-URLs
input_schema.description: Pseudo-URLs to match links in the page that you want to enqueue. Combine with Link selector to tell the scraper where to find links. Omitting the Pseudo-URLs will cause the scraper to enqueue all links matched by the Link selector.

input_schema.name: Link selector
input_schema.description: CSS selector matching elements with 'href' attributes that should be enqueued. To enqueue urls from

input_schema.name: Keep URL fragments
input_schema.description: URL fragments (the parts of URL after a #) are not considered when the scraper determines whether a URL has already been visited. This means that when adding URLs such as https://example.com/#foo and https://example.com/#bar, only the first will be visited. Turn this option on to tell the scraper to visit both.

input_schema.name: Page function
input_schema.description: Function executed for each request

input_schema.name: jQuery
input_schema.description: The jQuery library will be injected into each page. If the page already uses jQuery, conflicts may arise.

input_schema.name: Underscore
input_schema.description: The Underscore.js library will be injected into each page. If the page already uses Underscore.js (or other libraries that attach to '_', such as Lodash), conflicts may arise.

input_schema.name: Proxy configuration
input_schema.description: Choose to use no proxy, Apify Proxy, or provide custom proxy URLs.

input_schema.name: Initial cookies
input_schema.description: The provided cookies will be pre-set to all pages the scraper opens.

input_schema.name: Use Chrome
input_schema.description: The scraper will use a real Chrome browser instead of a Chromium masking as Chrome. Using this option may help with bypassing certain anti-scraping protections, but risks that the scraper will be unstable or not work at all.

input_schema.name: Use Stealth
input_schema.description: The scraper will apply various browser emulation techniques to match a real user as closely as possible. This feature works best in conjunction with the Use Chrome option and also carries the risk of making the scraper unstable.

input_schema.name: Ignore SSL errors
input_schema.description: Scraper will ignore SSL certificate errors.

input_schema.name: Ignore CORS and CSP
input_schema.description: Scraper will ignore CSP (content security policy) and CORS (cross origin resource sharing) settings of visited pages and requested domains. This enables you to freely use XHR/Fetch to make HTTP requests from the scraper.

input_schema.name: Download media
input_schema.description: Scraper will download media such as images, fonts, videos and sounds. Disabling this may speed up the scrape, but certain websites could stop working correctly.

input_schema.name: Download CSS
input_schema.description: Scraper will download CSS stylesheets. Disabling this may speed up the scrape, but certain websites could stop working correctly.

input_schema.name: Max request retries
input_schema.description: Maximum number of times the request for the page will be retried in case of an error. Setting it to 0 means that the request will be attempted once and will not be retried if it fails.

input_schema.name: Max pages per run
input_schema.description: Maximum number of pages that the scraper will open. 0 means unlimited.

input_schema.name: Max result records
input_schema.description: Maximum number of results that will be saved to dataset. The scraper will terminate afterwards. 0 means unlimited.

input_schema.name: Max crawling depth
input_schema.description: Defines how many links away from the StartURLs will the scraper descend. 0 means unlimited.

input_schema.name: Max concurrency
input_schema.description: Defines how many pages can be processed by the scraper in parallel. The scraper automatically increases and decreases concurrency based on available system resources. Use this option to set a hard limit.

input_schema.name: Page load timeout
input_schema.description: Maximum time the scraper will allow a web page to load in seconds.

input_schema.name: Page function timeout
input_schema.description: Maximum time the scraper will wait for the page function to execute in seconds.

input_schema.name: Navigation wait until
input_schema.description: The scraper will wait until the selected events are triggered in the page before executing the page function. Available events are domcontentloaded, load, networkidle2 and networkidle0. See Puppeteer docs.

input_schema.name: Debug log
input_schema.description: Debug messages will be included in the log. Use context.log.debug('message') to log your own debug messages.

input_schema.name: Browser log
input_schema.description: Console messages from the Browser will be included in the log. This may result in the log being flooded by error messages, warnings and other messages of little value, especially with high concurrency.

input_schema.name: Chrome debugger [experimental]
input_schema.description: Experimental implementation of Chrome debugger. In this mode the scraper will run with single browser on concurrency 1. You can place debugger; into your page function to set up a debugger breakpoint.

input_schema.name: Custom data
input_schema.description: This object will be available on pageFunction's context as customData.

input_schema.name: The URL of the store you want to scrape
input_schema.description: Example: https://www.ubereats.com/nz/store/pizza-hut-newtown/8F10LUogSqWYO1ajzth5sQ

input_schema.name: 🔑 Token
input_schema.description:
How to get Token value ?

Access <a target="_blank" href=https://bard.google.com>Google Bard AI
Search for cookie named: __Secure-1PSID
then copy and paste here.

input_schema.name: 👁️‍🗨️ Keep Context

input_schema.name: URLs to check
input_schema.description:
A static list of URLs to check for captchas. To be able to add new URLs on the fly, enable the Use request queue option.

For details, see Start URLs in README.

input_schema.name: Proxy Configuration
input_schema.description:
Specifies proxy servers that will be used by the scraper in order to hide its origin.

For details, see Proxy configuration in README.

input_schema.name: Enabled
input_schema.description: Will save HTML for Cheerio and HTML + screenshot for Puppeteer/Playwright

input_schema.name: Link Selector
input_schema.description:
A CSS selector saying which links on the page (<a> elements with href attribute) shall be followed and added to the request queue. This setting only applies if Use request queue is enabled. To filter the links added to the queue, use the Pseudo-URLs setting.

If Link selector is empty, the page links are ignored.

For details, see Link selector in README.

input_schema.name: Pseudo-URLs
input_schema.description:
Specifies what kind of URLs found by Link selector should be added to the request queue. A pseudo-URL is a URL with regular expressions enclosed in [] brackets, e.g. http://www.example.com/[.*]. This setting only applies if the Use request queue option is enabled.

If Pseudo-URLs are omitted, the actor enqueues all links matched by the Link selector.

For details, see Pseudo-URLs in README.

input_schema.name: Repeat checks on provided URLs
input_schema.description: Will access each URL multiple times. Useful to test the same URL or bypass blocking of the first page.

input_schema.name: Max number of pages checked per domain
input_schema.description:
The maximum number of pages that the checker will load. The checker will stop when this limit is reached. It's always a good idea to set this limit in order to prevent excess platform usage for misconfigured scrapers. Note that the actual number of pages loaded might be slightly higher than this value.

If set to 0, there is no limit.

input_schema.name: Maximum concurrent pages checked per domain
input_schema.description: Specifies the maximum number of pages that can be processed by the checker in parallel for one domain. The checker automatically increases and decreases concurrency based on available system resources. This option enables you to set an upper limit, for example to reduce the load on a target website.

input_schema.name: Maximum number of concurrent domains checked
input_schema.description: Specifies the maximum number of domains that should be checked at a time. This setting is relevant when passing in more than one URL to check.

input_schema.name: Retire browser instance after request count
input_schema.description: How often will the browser itself rotate. Pick a higher number for smaller consumption, pick a lower number to rotate (test) more proxies.

input_schema.name: Max concurrency

input_schema.name: Output format
input_schema.description: Format to which the input file will be converted. Can be the same format. Should be written like file extension.

input_schema.name: Ffmpeg command options
input_schema.description: List of command-line options to be passed to ffmpeg. It can be either an array of option arguments, e.g. ["-c:v", "libx264"] or a single line that will be split by whitespace. Don't provide input or output arguments! Docs is here: https://www.ffmpeg.org

input_schema.name: Start URLs
input_schema.description:
A static list of URLs to scrape.

For details, see the Start URLs section in the README.

input_schema.name: URL #fragments identify unique pages
input_schema.description: Indicates that URL fragments (e.g. http://example.com#fragment) should be included when checking whether a URL has already been visited or not. Typically, URL fragments are used for page navigation only and therefore they should be ignored, as they don't identify separate pages. However, some single-page websites use URL fragments to display different pages; in such cases, this option should be enabled.

input_schema.name: Glob Patterns
input_schema.description: Glob patterns to match links in the page that you want to enqueue. Combine with Link selector to tell the scraper where to find links. Omitting the Glob patterns will cause the scraper to enqueue all links matched by the Link selector.

input_schema.name: Pseudo-URLs
input_schema.description:
Specifies what kind of URLs found by the Link selector should be added to the request queue. A pseudo-URL is a URL with regular expressions enclosed in [] brackets, e.g. http://www.example.com/[.*].

If Pseudo-URLs are omitted, the actor enqueues all links matched by the Link selector.

For details, see Pseudo-URLs in README.

input_schema.name: Exclude Glob Patterns
input_schema.description: Glob patterns to match links in the page that you want to exclude from being enqueued.

input_schema.name: Link selector
input_schema.description:
A CSS selector stating which links on the page (<a> elements with href attribute) shall be followed and added to the request queue. To filter the links added to the queue, use the Pseudo-URLs and/or Glob patterns field.

If the Link selector is empty, the page links are ignored.

For details, see the Link selector in README.

input_schema.name: Run scripts
input_schema.description: Whether to execute JavaScript in the downloaded page. If enabled, the JSDOM engine will process the JavaScript in the page as if it was loaded in a browser. This is useful for pages that use JavaScript to render the content, but it can also cause secuirty issues.

input_schema.name: Show internal console logs
input_schema.description: Whether to show internal JSDOM console logs in the log output. This is useful for debugging the page function and seeing what's happening in the JSDOM environment.

input_schema.name: Page function
input_schema.description:
A JavaScript function that is executed for every page loaded server-side in Node.js 12. Use it to scrape data from the page, perform actions or add new URLs to the request queue.

For details, see Page function in README.

input_schema.name: Proxy configuration
input_schema.description:
Specifies proxy servers that will be used by the scraper in order to hide its origin.

For details, see Proxy configuration in README.

input_schema.name: Proxy rotation
input_schema.description: This property indicates the strategy of proxy rotation and can only be used in conjunction with Apify Proxy. The recommended setting automatically picks the best proxies from your available pool and rotates them evenly, discarding proxies that become blocked or unresponsive. If this strategy does not work for you for any reason, you may configure the scraper to either use a new proxy for each request, or to use one proxy as long as possible, until the proxy fails. IMPORTANT: This setting will only use your available Apify Proxy pool, so if you don't have enough proxies for a given task, no rotation setting will produce satisfactory results.

input_schema.name: Session pool name
input_schema.description: Use only english alphanumeric characters dashes and underscores. A session is a representation of a user. It has it's own IP and cookies which are then used together to emulate a real user. Usage of the sessions is controlled by the Proxy rotation option. By providing a session pool name, you enable sharing of those sessions across multiple actor runs. This is very useful when you need specific cookies for accessing the websites or when a lot of your proxies are already blocked. Instead of trying randomly, a list of working sessions will be saved and a new actor run can reuse those sessions. Note that the IP lock on sessions expires after 24 hours, unless the session is used again in that window.

input_schema.name: Initial cookies
input_schema.description: A JSON array with cookies that will be send with every HTTP request made by the JSDOM Scraper, in the format accepted by the tough-cookie NPM package. This option is useful for transferring a logged-in session from an external web browser. For details how to do this, read this help article.

input_schema.name: Additional MIME types
input_schema.description: A JSON array specifying additional MIME content types of web pages to support. By default, JSDOM Scraper supports the text/html and application/xhtml+xml content types, and skips all other resources. For details, see Content types in README.

input_schema.name: Suggest response encoding
input_schema.description: The scraper automatically determines response encoding from the response headers. If the headers are invalid or information is missing, malformed responses may be produced. Use the Suggest response encoding option to provide a fall-back encoding to the Scraper for cases where it could not be determined.

input_schema.name: Force response encoding
input_schema.description: If enabled, the suggested response encoding will be used even if a valid response encoding is provided by the target website. Use this only when you've inspected the responses thoroughly and are sure that they are the ones doing it wrong.

input_schema.name: Ignore SSL errors
input_schema.description: If enabled, the scraper will ignore SSL/TLS certificate errors. Use at your own risk.

input_schema.name: Pre-navigation hooks
input_schema.description: Async functions that are sequentially evaluated before the navigation. Good for setting additional cookies or browser properties before navigation. The function accepts two parameters, crawlingContext and requestAsBrowserOptions, which are passed to the requestAsBrowser() function the crawler calls to navigate.

input_schema.name: Post-navigation hooks
input_schema.description: Async functions that are sequentially evaluated after the navigation. Good for checking if the navigation was successful. The function accepts crawlingContext as the only parameter.

input_schema.name: Max request retries
input_schema.description:
The maximum number of times the scraper will retry to load each web page on error, in case of a page load error or an exception thrown by the Page function.

If set to 0, the page will be considered failed right after the first error.

input_schema.name: Max pages per run
input_schema.description:
The maximum number of pages that the scraper will load. The scraper will stop when this limit is reached. It is always a good idea to set this limit in order to prevent excess platform usage for misconfigured scrapers. Note that the actual number of pages loaded might be slightly higher than this value.

If set to 0, there is no limit.

input_schema.name: Max result records
input_schema.description:
The maximum number of records that will be saved to the resulting dataset. The scraper will stop when this limit is reached.

If set to 0, there is no limit.

input_schema.name: Max crawling depth
input_schema.description:
Specifies how many links away from the Start URLs the scraper will descend. This value is a safeguard against infinite crawling depths for misconfigured scrapers. Note that pages added using context.enqueuePage() in Page function are not subject to the maximum depth constraint.

If set to 0, there is no limit.

input_schema.name: Max concurrency
input_schema.description: Specifies the maximum number of pages that can be processed by the scraper in parallel. The scraper automatically increases and decreases concurrency based on available system resources. This option enables you to set an upper limit, for example to reduce the load on a target web server.

input_schema.name: Page load timeout
input_schema.description: The maximum amount of time the scraper will wait for a web page to load, in seconds. If the web page does not load in this timeframe, it is considered to have failed and will be retried (subject to Max page retries), similarly as with other page load errors.

input_schema.name: Page function timeout
input_schema.description: The maximum amount of time the scraper will wait for the Page function to execute, in seconds. It is always a good idea to set this limit, to ensure that unexpected behavior in page function will not get the scraper stuck.

input_schema.name: Enable debug log
input_schema.description: If enabled, the actor log will include debug messages. Beware that this can be quite verbose. Use context.log.debug('message') to log your own debug messages from the Page function.

input_schema.name: Custom data
input_schema.description: A custom JSON object that is passed to the Page function as context.customData. This setting is useful when invoking the scraper via API, in order to pass some arbitrary parameters to your code.

input_schema.name: Dataset name
input_schema.description: Name or ID of the dataset that will be used for storing results. If left empty, the default dataset of the run will be used.

input_schema.name: Key-value store name
input_schema.description: Name or ID of the key-value store that will be used for storing records. If left empty, the default key-value store of the run will be used.

input_schema.name: Request queue name
input_schema.description: Name of the request queue that will be used for storing requests. If left empty, the default request queue of the run will be used.

input_schema.name: OpenAI API Key
input_schema.description: Paste your OpenAI API Key here.

input_schema.name: Your Question
input_schema.description: Write Your Question here.

input_schema.name: Start URLs

input_schema.name: Unique Column
input_schema.description: Column name from results to use as Key for Key-Value Storage. For example: product_id (must be unique).

input_schema.name: Input
input_schema.description: Hepsiburada single product URL or search query. You can enter multiple items, one per line.

input_schema.name: Max items
input_schema.description: Enter the maximum number of items you want to scrape. This will let the scraper know when to stop. Maximum is 500, minimum is 10. Default is 100.

input_schema.name: Proxy configuration
input_schema.description: Select proxies to be used by your crawler.

input_schema.name: Apify Storage ID
input_schema.description: Id of dataset or key value store where the data are located.

input_schema.name: Record Key
input_schema.description: Only specify if Apify storage id points to a key value store! This is the record key under which the data are.

input_schema.name: Raw Data
input_schema.description: Raw JSON array you want to check.

input_schema.name: Functional Checker
input_schema.description: Function that returns an object with item fields as keys and values as predicates (functions that return true/false)

input_schema.name: Context
input_schema.description: Custom object where you can put any value that will be accessible in functional checker functions as third parameter. Useful for dynamic values coming from other actors.

input_schema.name: Identification Fields
input_schema.description: You can specify which fields should display in the debug OUTPUT to identify bad items. By default it shows all fields which may make it unnecessary big.

input_schema.name: Minimal success rate
input_schema.description: You can specify minimal success rate (0 to 1) of any field. If the success rate will be higher than this, the field will not be count as bad field. This needs t obe an object with fields as keys and success rate as values.

input_schema.name: No extra fields
input_schema.description: If checked on, the actor will consider extra fields as bad fields. Uncheck if you don't mind them

input_schema.name: Limit
input_schema.description: How many items will be checked. Default is all

input_schema.name: Offset
input_schema.description: From which item the checking will start. Use with limit to check specific items.

input_schema.name: Batch Size
input_schema.description: You can change number of loaded and processed items in each batch. This is only needed if you have really huge items.

input_schema.name: Max bad items saved
input_schema.description: Sets how big report you get for each unique combination of bad fields. Keeping this small and running it again after fixing some is the best approach. It speeds up the actor and reduces memory need.

input_schema.description: Course URLs to scrape.

input_schema.description: Page number to start scraping from.

input_schema.name: Target number of results
input_schema.description: If set, only up to this number of entries will be extracted. The actual number of entries might be higher than this because the results are paginated.

input_schema.name: Proxy configuration
input_schema.description: Select proxies to be used by your crawler.

input_schema.name: Include personal data
input_schema.description:
By default, fields that are potential personal data are censored. Toggle this option on to get the un-uncensored values.

WARNING: Turn this on ONLY if you have consent, legal basis for using the data, or at your own risk. Learn more

input_schema.name: Dataset ID or name
input_schema.description: By default, data is written to Default dataset. Set this option if you want to write data to non-default dataset. Learn more

input_schema.name: Rename dataset fields
input_schema.description:
Select a subset of fields of an entry that will be pushed to the dataset.

If not set, all fields on an entry will be pushed to the dataset.

This is done before outputRenameFields.

Keys can be nested, e.g. "someProp.value[0]". Nested path is resolved using Lodash.get().

input_schema.name: Rename dataset fields
input_schema.description:
Rename fields (columns) of the output data.

If not set, all fields will have their original names.

This is done after outputPickFields.

Keys can be nested, e.g. "someProp.value[0]". Nested path is resolved using Lodash.get().

input_schema.name: Metamorph actor ID - metamorph to another actor at the end
input_schema.description:
Use this option if you want to run another actor with the same dataset after this actor has finished (AKA metamorph into another actor). Learn more

New actor is identified by its ID, e.g. "apify/web-scraper".

input_schema.name: Metamorph actor build
input_schema.description: Tag or number of the target actor build to metamorph into (e.g. 'beta' or '1.2.345')

input_schema.name: Metamorph actor input
input_schema.description: Input object passed to the follow-up (metamorph) actor. Learn more

input_schema.name: maxRequestRetries
input_schema.description: Indicates how many times the request is retried if BasicCrawlerOptions.requestHandler fails.

input_schema.name: maxRequestsPerMinute
input_schema.description: The maximum number of requests per minute the crawler should run. We can pass any positive, non-zero integer.

input_schema.name: maxRequestsPerCrawl
input_schema.description:
Maximum number of pages that the crawler will open. The crawl will stop when this limit is reached.

NOTE: In cases of parallel crawling, the actual number of pages visited might be slightly higher than this value.

input_schema.name: minConcurrency
input_schema.description:
Sets the minimum concurrency (parallelism) for the crawl.

WARNING: If we set this value too high with respect to the available system memory and CPU, our crawler will run extremely slow or crash. If not sure, it's better to keep the default value and the concurrency will scale up automatically.

input_schema.name: maxConcurrency
input_schema.description: Sets the maximum concurrency (parallelism) for the crawl.

input_schema.name: navigationTimeoutSecs
input_schema.description: Timeout in which the HTTP request to the resource needs to finish, given in seconds.

input_schema.name: requestHandlerTimeoutSecs
input_schema.description: Timeout in which the function passed as BasicCrawlerOptions.requestHandler needs to finish, in seconds.

input_schema.name: keepAlive
input_schema.description: Allows to keep the crawler alive even if the RequestQueue gets empty. With keepAlive: true the crawler will keep running, waiting for more requests to come.

input_schema.name: additionalMimeTypes
input_schema.description: An array of MIME types you want the crawler to load and process. By default, only text/html and application/xhtml+xml MIME types are supported.

input_schema.name: suggestResponseEncoding
input_schema.description: By default this crawler will extract correct encoding from the HTTP response headers. There are some websites which use invalid headers. Those are encoded using the UTF-8 encoding. If those sites actually use a different encoding, the response will be corrupted. You can use suggestResponseEncoding to fall back to a certain encoding, if you know that your target website uses it. To force a certain encoding, disregarding the response headers, use forceResponseEncoding.

input_schema.name: forceResponseEncoding
input_schema.description: By default this crawler will extract correct encoding from the HTTP response headers. Use forceResponseEncoding to force a certain encoding, disregarding the response headers. To only provide a default for missing encodings, use suggestResponseEncoding.

input_schema.name: Log Level
input_schema.description: Select how detailed should be the logging.

input_schema.name: Error reporting dataset ID
input_schema.description:
Apify dataset ID or name to which errors should be captured.

Default: 'REPORTING'.

input_schema.name: Send errors to Sentry
input_schema.description:
Whether to send actor error reports to Sentry.

This info is used by the author of this actor to identify broken integrations, and track down and fix issues.

input_schema.name: #️⃣ Total number of records required
input_schema.description: Leave this field empty if you want to scrape all items.

input_schema.name: Proxy
input_schema.description: To scrape this website you mostly need a residential proxy

input_schema.name: ⏱️ Minimum wait duration
input_schema.description: Minimum duration in seconds to wait before scraping next page

input_schema.name: ⏱️ Maximum wait duration
input_schema.description: Maximum duration in seconds to wait before scraping next page

input_schema.name: Enter Shopee product Urls
input_schema.description: Product URLs of Shopee

input_schema.description: Select your Shopee country
